text: If there are still low income people living in these neighborhoods, they've gotten to this point in a development regime that's far less protective of renters than SB 50 will be. I can't see how SB 50 would make things worse for them; easy to see how it could make things better.

text: It's pretty cool how, despite a few hundred years as a nation, many changes, and much growth, we've reached a zenith where every single neighborhood in America is perfect just as it is, and any change whatsoever could only make things worse. We made it you guys!

text: I think the challenge is that everyone speculates on housing in the U.S. Every homebuyer buys with the expectation/hope of increasing value -- it's literally the definition of speculation!
author: ShaneDPhillips

text: For the record, I'm going to try to do the same with people who regularly conflate self-interested NIMBYs with equity- and justice-minded people genuinely concerned with gentrification and displacement. Thankfully I don't run into many of them on here.

text: I'm always open to thoughtful conversations, but for my own mental health going forward, I'm just blocking anyone I see making blanket statements about "what YIMBYs stand for." I don't need this pointless "discourse" in my life.

text: Also a good analogy! Even better in many ways.
author: ShaneDPhillips

text: Or if not instructive, at least useful. Housing is about politics as much as (probably more than) anything else, so being able to explain complicated topics in approachable ways is important, even if you're losing some nuance in the process.
author: ShaneDPhillips

text: I actually agree that each piece of land is unique, and that the economic theories we apply to consumable goods don't apply perfectly to housing/land. But they do still apply in meaningful ways, so I think analogies can still be instructive.
author: ShaneDPhillips

text: Fair enough, and I appreciate that. But I think applying the critique that "housing is unique and weird" to an analogy sort of boils down to saying *no* analogy would be appropriate, because nothing is comparable. And I still think there's value in analogies, even imperfect ones.
author: ShaneDPhillips

text: "It's like I can't win" is the motto of every person walking or bicycling in America.
author: ShaneDPhillips

text: Okay man, but just to be clear you came into this assuming the least charitable understanding of these issues on my part. It was an analogy, not a thesis, and not even in exactly my own words.
author: ShaneDPhillips

text: And I'm not sure if people are directly arguing that 0% vacancy is desirable, but they're definitely saying we have 100,000+ vacant housing units and that this is an argument against building more housing. It follows that they think a much lower vacancy rate would be good.
author: ShaneDPhillips

text: It strikes me that it's even more true of housing than for Amazon goods precisely *because* housing is weird. It's not interchangeable and so the friction -- leading to less than perfect utilization/efficiency -- is more pronounced.
author: ShaneDPhillips

text: Can you explain why that matters all that much? The point is that in either case there's necessary friction in the market. Wishing it didn't exist doesn't make it any less the reality.
author: ShaneDPhillips

text: Have I got news for all of you.
author: ShaneDPhillips

text:
Read this today and thought it was a great analogy: 

"Saying the vacancy rate should be 0% because houses should always be occupied is like saying Amazon warehouses should be empty because the inventory should be in consumers’ homes."

text: Even if the app isn't fixed in short order, it'd be great if the workers were trained to investigate beyond the address listed, based on photos (which I always take) and any additional info in the notes section.
author: ShaneDPhillips

text: It feels like if they don't see anything at the address listed then they file it as canceled, or as a duplicate if it matches the address of a previous request, even though they're not actually at the same location -- the app just isn't giving me a new one.
author: ShaneDPhillips

text: Marmion Way between Highland Park and Cypress Park was a good example of the latter, because there aren't actual addresses along some stretches. I have started putting cross-streets in the notes, but I'm not sure the BSS workers actually reads them.
author: ShaneDPhillips

text: I've had a few different issues, including the app giving me the same address for multiple requests at different locations (despite clicking "new request at different location") as well as some places just not providing addresses at all.
author: ShaneDPhillips

text: Actually Greg @Spottnik, I've had an issue with many of my requests getting canceled because they either can't be found or are classified as "duplicate." Neither should be the case, but the address/GPS function is very unreliable. Is there work being done to improve it?
